Posts.Content: I would get a second opinion ------------ always. I would go with the doctor recommends, because if the surgery does not get it all, then Salvage Radiation probably will. I you do radiation first and it don't work. Then you cannot have surgery (based on what I have read). Chrisz

Posts.Title: Who to see to decide what's the best treatment to follow? Clear as mud

Posts.Content: I've been through this PCa scare-thing for 8 years. My PSA keeps going up and down. Up to 15 then next PSA down to 3.0. PSA now 12. Free and Total PSA look bad. Udoc wants another Biopsy. My 3rd Biopsy (one was a saturation biopsy), with my third different Udoc. Lately I have loss my desire for sex, and before that I had the desire, but hard to get an erection. I've tried 3 different ED meds, none help even a little bit. Mdoc and Udoc both did not seem to know why. I am 61 years old. Wife doesn't seem to care that I don't want sex.... In fact, she seems happy. So, do you think PCa can cause this ? I do have BPH, may it could cause it ?
Posts.Title: Can PCa cause loss of Libido and ED.

Posts.Content: Sometimes I believe that Udocs are quick to give Biopsy's. Could it be ???????? The Money ???????? This PSA thing has made many doctors mucho money ! It also causes many patients undo worry. Your PSA is more indicative of infection or inflammation. Your doctor knows this, I'm almost 100% sure. I had my PSA bounce like you. My free PSA was also bad. Two biopsy's later (and 4 years) my PSA is normal again. Yet, I still could have cancer. But it is unlikely. Same with you. In my opinion only. Chris

Posts.Content: I think the freezing feeling is caused by your medication. I may be wrong. Check with your Udoc.
Posts.Title: I'm freezing and don't know why

Posts.Content: I think the freezing feeling is caused by your medication. I may be wrong. Check with your Udoc.
Posts.Title: I'm freezing and don't know why

Posts.Content: To make a 12 year story short: My first BIOPSY with a PSA of 4.6 11 years ago was negative. Later the same UR doc wanted to do another. I told him I was going to get a second opinion. The next UR doc found infection in my Prostate seminal fluid. But antibiotics did not work. He wanted to do a "Saturation Biopsy" at the hospital. I went, 30 cores later and it was negative. Later this second UR doc wanted me to under go another "Saturation Biopsy". I told him I was going to get another opinion. The third UR doc took a 2 month wait and HE wanted to do standard biopsy. It was negative for PCa but positive for inflammation . All three doctors told me that they thought I had Prostate cancer before they did they $$ Biopsy's. My PSA was going from 3 to 15 and hanging somewhere in between. Free PSA also looked bad ! The last doctor is still the one I see. After a negative biopsy, he put me on Proscar 5mg a day for 6 months. He told me that the Proscar will shrink my Prostate, but not High Grade Prostate Cancer. My PSA went from 15 down to 1.5 and is 1.1 (Double that because of the Proscar) and you get 2.2. Now I am on Proscar 5mg every other day. So all of this time my high PSA was from a moderately enlarged Prostate and maybe inflammation. So don't worry right away if you have a PSA that is high. It can be caused by several other factors other than Pca. Unfortunately, for me, it gave me great anxiety for the last 12 years. I know many lives have been saved because of PSA testing and I glad for you. But PSA is not a Prostate Cancer test ! Chris
Posts.Title: PSA took me for a ride !

Posts.Content: Small enough to miss on biopsy ??? I don't think so. If you can feel it, then you certainly can stick a needle in it. And they probably did it several times. Everyone thinks high PSA means cancer on this Forum it seems. I've been running a PSA that varies from 2.5 up to 15 and then months later revert back to 2.5. Some men walk around with PSA readings in the double digits, but no cancer. A lot of unnecessary biopsy's, however; making doctors a lot of money. But me ? For 9 years I have living with the fear of prostate cancer. If I had it to do over, I would never have a PSA test done. In fact after tomorrow,(I'm having my third biopsy, one was a 25 core saturation biopsy done at the hospital) if it comes back negative again, NO MORE PSA TESTING ON ME. I'll wait until they can feel it on DRE. A friend of my had a Physical done on my suggestion. (He had never had one and was 57 years old). His PSA was 2.1. Upon DRE the Udoc found a lump on his prostate. A biopsy was positive for cancer. Lucky it had not escaped the prostate. He had it removed several years ago and no re-occurrence. In this case the PSA reading was meaningless. My Udoc (this is my third, but I trust him more) said that if it's negative again, he is going to give me one of the drugs that shrink the prostate. He said it will shrink the prostate, but if there is cancer in it, it won't shrink the cancer. Then he "should" be able to find it with a DRE. We will see. I guess the point I am trying to make is: if your PSA is low, it doesn't mean you DON'T have cancer, and if it is high it doesn't mean you DO have prostate cancer. Further investigation should be instigated if it IS HIGH, but even a biopsy won't tell you for sure.

AgeInfo.Phrase: never had one and was 57 years old <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: I would go for the Surgery, then if that doesn't get it all, you can have Salvage Radiation done. It is untrue that you can't have both. I have a friend of mine who was cured this way. However, I don't know about having radiation and then the surgery later. I am also not sure why a doctor needs to have done 500 + surgeries before doing yours. I've never read that statistic and like to know where it came from. Check out You Tube Videos on prostate cancer. From what I read, if the doctor has done as few as 50 da vinci's he is ready. But I guess that question is VERY subjective. If the cancer has not spread from the Prostate, which it apparently hasn't in your case, then the cure rate is high. It had spread with my uncle, so he had no surgery at all, yet he lived for 16 years after DX. PSA is not a cancer test. I've been through Hell with Biopsy's for the last 8 years because the numbers look bad, but, so-far I have not been diagnosed with PC. My PSA has been up to 18 and back down to 3. No symptoms except a little BPH.

Posts.Title: Update with pathology report

Posts.Content: " Isn't it better to find and treat prostate cancer early? Once prostate cancer is detected, doctors try their best to determine whether the cancer is dangerous. But the truth is in many cases, nobody knows for sure. Here's what some of the experts say: Susan G. Fisher, PhD, professor and chair of preventive medicine at the University of Rochester, N.Y.: "Right now we do not have an accurate marker to identify people who have prostate cancer that could eventually cause serious problems for them." Otis Brawley, MD, chief science officer of the American Cancer Society: "It is very well accepted that 40% to 60% of localized prostate cancers that we cure are in men who did not need to be cured." Barnett S. Kramer, MD, MPH, director of the office of disease prevention at the National Institutes of Health: "Unfortunately right now we are left with diagnosing a large number of people without precise enough knowledge to spare those who don't need to be treated from treatment." But a healthy man who is told he has cancer no longer feels like a healthy man. In the U.S., most such men will seek treatment."
Posts.Title: Does that Cancer really need to be removed ?

Posts.Title: Habanero Peppers / Capsaicin questions.

Posts.Content: We once had a gentlemen on here that said that Habanero peppers ( Capsaicin tablets ) cured his late stage cancer. This is the same regime that Don Imus is on. http://www.naturalnews.com/026076_PS...in_cancer.html Does anyone know if there is more evidence that it works ? I've suffered up and down PSA's for years. I agreed to have another biopsy on DEC 20. This will be my third and first one in 3 years. I'm thinking that I do now have PC. If I had incurable PC I would definitely go on it. And I might go on it, even if it is treatable. Chris
